column1: How many seats in Poland's Sejm will PiS (Law and Justice) win in the upcoming parliamentary elections?
column6: ['Non-US Politics']

Exit poll showed the conservative Law and Justice party winning with 39 percent of the vote, enough to govern alone without forming a coalition. The pro-European Civic Platform party received 23 percent of the vote, according to the exit poll. Official polling results are expected Monday.
It already happened

Based on early reports from exit polls (http://www.politico.eu/article/polands-government-defeated-in-parliamentary-elections-2/) PiS got 39% CP got 23% KuK got 9% Now got 7% PPP got 5% and 17% went to parties that didn't make the threshold.
Maybe the exit polls will end up being wrong, but I'm not holding my breath they'll be wrong enough.
Majority - 95% Plurality - 5% Not a Plurality - 0%
Catching up.

Poland has a long history with the USSR and they haven't forgotten the price they payed to be free of it. The effect of the immigrant crisis on the attitudes of the Polish people may impact the election. If Russia takes the rest of the Ukraine there will no doubt be those that my feel it is safer to be a friend of a close threat than an ally of a distant friend.

The parliamentary election, Poland appears to join the region’s rightward drift toward nationalism and toss out the center-right party that has governed the country for eight years.

I think it's too far to get the majority. The obviously will win the most votes though, so non-plurailty isn't a question... Doubtful to get majority given the history of polish elections

Again listening to an article in this week Economist. Country growth by a third, the East feels neglected and punished by politicians, hence PiS popularity "only PiS cares". The big question is how far west will PiS influence go? PiS is intent on gaining a majority. POs cafe troubles seem to have helped PiS get over some of its past. Child subsidy 500 zloty per child could be attractive to working families throughout the country.[£84/$129 per month]. Some want to emigrate if PiS wins, which will hold them back, as clearly some voters would be uncomfortable staying with them in power. Todays Guardian says "It is not clear if Law and Justice will win enough votes to govern alone or if it will need a coalition partner." and "The Roman Catholic church backs Law and Justice, which many analysts say will help it claim victory" http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/25/polish-parliamentary-election-vote-2015 Overall, I am upping my forecast by 2%
Chicken adjustment. That said, I love my pet chickens, and acting "chicken" is how they keep from becoming coyote dinners.
Shador13 seems to think that PiS will gain a majority. He's a local, so I'll go with him.
http://news.yahoo.com/polls-predict-solid-conservative-victory-poland-204029744.html
The weather forecast is looking dry which could work in PiS favour given their core voters. Hence I am notching up for a majority.
Reaffirming forecast

Strange one, having just read the question on Turkey, I am wondering how aligned that will be with Poland. Given what has just happened in Turkey, which while being out of the EU is close enough for human social and economic dynamics to be reflected. In Turkeys question it is noted that "he Justice and Development Party (AKP) failed to win a single-party majority in June's general election for the first time since 2002. After negotiations aimed at forming a coalition government collapsed, snap elections have been scheduled ". So the main party lost, and coalition failed. This again suggests change in this part of the world (though again note in the UK we re-elected the incumbents, but much more strongly from a coalition to outright). the "omens" suggest to me that this "energy" will be reflected in Poland for a majority. I am upping my majority prediction a little.

https://euobserver.com/political/130821 is still forecasting a coalition though with one poll showing PiS doing really well 40.5%, the other 32.5%. While I still think that they will do far better than expected I am revising down a little, partially because I have just read that they are going to raise the retirement age which will alienate some older workers.
I'm strapped for time and having to do triage by relying on others because I don't have the time to research this myself.

overall wish there was better coverage of the polls with this election. Wikipedia references seem to be incomplete and some articles don't identify which polls they're referencing. Wishful thinking aside...
following wisdom of crowd...
Revising after discussion with Polish friend

Now from looking at Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sejm#Most_recent_election in the last election Civic Platform lost 2 seats, and law and Justice (PIS) lost 9. Given Pis (from this weeks Economist) are offering something for everyone, with social welfare promises in these tough times, and also tapping into immigration issues, and explaining the benefits of majority rule, I think that they will regain what they lost last time. Also taking account of the polls at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_parliamentary_election,_2015#/media/File:Model_sonda%C5%BCy.png I can't help but think that the party will do better than expected. But I do realize that this is unscientific, at the end of my nose, but this is my first forecast scenario. I also hope that I am not misunderstanding the question which asks "how many seats" but the forecast seems to be requiring a percentage confidence in a majority (presumably of any number of seats), clearly if I have misunderstood here this will be a bit screwey. On the basis that it is the percentage likelihood of a majority that is required, I am now upping my forecast.

According to Bloomberg Business : Parties need 5 percent to gain Sejm seats (coalitions need 8 percent. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-23/poland-election-how-sunday-s-vote-could-shake-up-europe and as I think it more likely that a single party will surge forwards, given that I now know that it is easier (albeit at low percentages) for single parties to take seats, I am revising upwards.

Ok, first ever attempt. Having listened to this weeks economist, I can see certain alignments with what happened in Britain earlier this year in terms of mood, and hence potential surprise. As I have to stick my finger in the air somewhere to start my first forecast, I am going for 70% majority, and I will see about refining it from there.

With 35.3% in the last poll (from wikipedia article https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_parliamentary_election,_2015) and a string of pretty consistent results in recent polls and time running out, I'm changing from 95 plurality to 98

Last two days of campaign in Poland. The debates didn't changed much. PiS managed to stop or even changed declining polls, PO submitted with election loss. PiS voters are more disciplined and with lower attendance this may be crucial. For me there is one question. Will ZL or Korwin jump into parliament? If not (former has to jump 8% mark for coalition), those votes will be lost. Which will help big parties.
A notch change...

How exactly seats come from constituencies is black magic, it looks like winner can add 10-15% of seats to pure D'Hondt expectations, with latest polls the line might be at least 39-40% of total votes, a bit more than they have today.
IBRIS poll of 10-20-15, suggest PIS could get 47% of seats, close enough to majority that I'm raising probability.

New poll out. Kukiz'15 maintaining >5%. PiS moving up. Boy is this gonna be close between plurality and majority (if you accept the polls). If you assume the remaining uncommitted voters will break the exact same way as the committed voters, PiS would get 39% of the total vote, which would put them over a majority if I used the "mysterious" seats/percentage factor of 6.0 (See Anneinak's forecast of 7-October). But, I'm going to add an extra assumption that the undecided voters do not break that way, but rather break more toward the minor parties. Who knows!?! lol So close. Exciting. (Now here's the rub. If I were predicting this exactly as I see it, I would predict it 50/50 plurality/majority. Yet, I'm willing to take the risk at 50/50 to pick one for the chance of somehow scoring better. This may reveal a defect in either my understanding of the scoring system, my risk tolerance, or both!) http://ewybory.eu/sondaz-ibris-dla-onetu-14-10-2015/

Major reason for PiS (Law and Justice) popularity is very strong animosity against PO (Civic Platform) (they won twice: 2007, 2011). Polish society are just fed up with their government. Plenty of scandals, affairs, and incompetence turned against PO and gave PiS huge chance to take even majority in October election. The farther the worse. We had an Example - shock on political scene, after Andrzej Duda (PiS) won Presidential Election, where polls showed Civic Platform candidate winning. But It's not so easy. Society is divided. PiS raises too much controversy beetwen people, and many voters will have to vote not "for PiS" but "against PO".

Coalition governments are the norm in Poland; while current opinion polls attribute the % share of vote to PiS in the high 30s (and in some cases even the low 40s), on the basis of past elections, this is unlikely to be sufficient to give them an outright majority in their own right. - eg at the last Sejm election in 2011 the leading party, PO, got over 39% of the votes cast, but were still 23 seats short of a majority. In the election before that, in 2007, PiS got a higher percentage still - similar to the most favourable figures for them given by the opinion polls at present - of 41.5%, but were still 21 seats short of a majority.

Following ckruger's analysis.

PO currently has the majority of seats in Parliament (205) while PIS has 157 seats. Will current polls have placed PI ahead of PO consistently over the last three months (Sept: PS-37.3%, POS 27.2; August: PIS 39.1%, POS 19%, July: PIS 40.3%, PO 26.7%). While it has maintained an average lead of 34.9% over three months against POS, there are several factors which could leave both parties with a marginal loss or gain: migration in to EU and increased anti-immigrant sentiment among the polish electorate. PO holds a consistently Center Right position while PIS maintains a variance in the spectrum from Center Right to Center Left. While it is likely that PO could maintain dominance in an election, it is unlikely to overcome the lead that PIS holds in the polls. A plurality is the most likely outcome in the October 25, 2015 election.
Could get its own majority: http://news.yahoo.com/polands-eurosceptic-opposition-tops-polls-possible-majority-104935918.html

The PiS party had 30% or 157 seats in the last election. Current polling has them at ~35-40% of the vote with PO the next closest at ~20-30%. PO had a drop in early 2015 after being the plurality and it could come back, however I think the most likely result is a PiS plurality. Given that PiS has not polled much over 40% it is unlikely without a geopolitical event to see them gain a majority.

Difficult to say without constituency polls, but the national numbers suggest it's highly unlikely that they will not at least gain a plurality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_parliamentary_election,_2015

The Polish system of seat allocation is more complicated than I thought. It seems seats are allocated by constituency (see http://www.sejm.gov.pl/english/sejm/pos.htm and http://www.nsd.uib.no/european_election_database/country/poland/parliamentary_elections.html; see the 41 Polish constituencies here: http://wybory2007.pkw.gov.pl/SJM/EN/WYN/M/1.htm) and not by the vote percentage obtained nationwide. That adds another level of uncertainty in forecasting a PiS majority vs. plurality. Ideally, one would need an accurate poll for each constituency to post an accurate forecast.

Suppose the %s in this report are correct, is the seats projection accurate? Is there a way to verify it? http://www.tvp.info/21608768/ipsos-dla-tvp-info-pis-moglby-rzadzic-samodzielnie-w-sejmie-cztery-ugrupowania PiS gets 35% and 235 seats (a majority), PO - 24%, Kukiz - 9%, PSL - 5%, the others are below the threshold.

Reading recent blogs and articles on the second round vote the numbers are getting closer and closer between a maj an plu vote but I do not think a non is possible. It will be one or the other of the two choices. But I will check back before the final day of forecasting to see what is happening.

I could not find published recent results of any polls showing a majority; key given the PR method of selection. The range seems to be 35-45, consistently in late 30s. Reports seem to indicate a majority is not possible at this time. As such believe a majority is very unlikely. Plurality seems the most likely outcome given the apparent collapse in support for the PO. For plurality not to occur, the PO would need to erode circa 13% lead, something that seems to have eluded them since the presidential elections in May 2015. As such, given the shift in presidential elections to PiS candidate that seems to still have good feeling in these elections,. see PiS pluraility in Sejm, but not enough votes to give a majority. Cannot see how they will not be the biggest party with such a lead and mood at this time. Will watch the polls to see the error of my ways unfold.
Following mparrault.

The PiS currently is leading with 37% of the vote, versus 24% for their nearest rival, the PO. They would need a bit less than 50% of the vote to win a majority. Based on those numbers alone, they are more likely to not win a plurality than win a majority (because they have to gain 13% of the vote to form a majority, and only lose 13%/2=6.5% to the PO to not win a plurality). In the American context, I would probably give an estimate like MaJ:2%, Plu:95%, NON: 3%. I understand that the polls significantly underestimated PiS support in the presidential election, so I will increase my odds for them winning a majority somewhat (although the polls could be wrong in the other direction this time, so I will also increase their odds for not winning a plurality). I am also increasing my odds for majority to align with the crowd.

swayed by the analysis and arguments of other forecasters

Poland is a divided nation politically. The PO (Civic Platform) Christian Democrats are stronger in the north. The PiS (Law and Justice) party is stronger in the South. Recent polls show some weakening but still a clear lead for the PiS. Since seats are proportionately allocated, I expect PiS to have a plurality but actions in Russia against the Ukraine or a Russian threat to Poland would drive the nation toward a more conservative stance and give the PiS a majority in this divided nation. There is very little probability at this time that the PiS will not achieve a plurality but one of the minor parties might have a sudden success, especially if Russian actions pose a real and present threat, making a more belligerent minor party more popular.

It's worth noting that the polls for the Presidential elections last May were wrong. None of them had Duda winning. The average of the final week's polls was 26.5%, well short of his actual first-round vote (34.8%). Could we see another opinion poll failure this time?

I have drawn extensively from previous informed forecasters assessments and refs. I credit:
The PO can't crack 30% in any recent polls, and the PiS hovers between 35-48%. A plurality for PiS is almost assured, while a majority is highly unlikely, barring a new scandal.
Current polls 2 seats short of majority: http://www.wsj.com/articles/poland-s-ruling-party-suffers-setback-in-referendum-1441650085

It seems that this election has a clear choice for the Polish people to make. The Sejm is the lower house of Parliament with 460 seats. Last May, Andrezj Duda, of the PiS, was elected President with 51.5% (2nd round), 34.76% (1st round) over Civic Platform (PO) Incumbent Komorowski (48.5%, 33.7%). The President's position is reportedly mostly ceremonial, except that it controls foreign policy. The PO currently controls Parliament with 207 seats to 157 for PiS. The PO outlook is pro European, based on European defense strategies, which currently non greatly in favor of militarizing Poland against Russia. Duda and the PiS seem more inclined to invite NATO and US troops into Poland and to create defense arraingements with other countries bordering on Russia. The PiS is less interested in EU initiatives like renewable energy, when Poland has large amounts of coal, or social issues, than the PO position offers. Parties are required to collect 5%, and coalitions 8%, of the vote to gain Parliamentary seats. The united Left coalition of "Your Movement" and "Democratic Left Alliance" parties have combined, but the wiki polls show their combined vote total at apprx. 4% to 12%. PiS seems to have a little momentum, and PO seems to have made a mistake with the referendum Anneinak referenced (called the refererendum out of desperation while losing the presidential election, yet only 8% of voters turned out for the referendum this week). Current polls give a 10% to 25% lead to PiS, while the United Left is in danger of falling below 8%, which seemingly would give a majority to PiS. A plurality seems certain, and a majority also seems likely, provided there is no protest by voters regarding the general direction of PiS policy.

Right now the current party has no chance of winning the elections. The frustrations in Poland are right now quite high, and people do not even know what is the good choice anymore. However, a large group of people made this strategy of not allowing either PiS or PO (current leader Party) get into Sejm. It's very hard to predict, but:
